episodes.title: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor arrested: Is anybody truly above the law?
episodes.description:
Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor – formerly known as Prince Andrew – was arrested while Harriet Harman and Ruth Davidson were recording this week's episode of the Electoral Dysfunction podcast. They were answering your questions for this half-term special episode of Electoral Dysfunction, while Beth Rigby was away on holiday.

In this breaking news episode, Harriet Harman and Ruth Davidson react to the extraordinary arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on suspicion of misconduct in public office, and discuss what it means for the rule of law, accountability and public trust in the United Kingdom.

But this episode is not just about Andrew.

The conversation is driven by listener questions, covering:

• The UK government’s latest U-turn on postponed local elections
• Whether Reform UK is facing proper scrutiny over its position on the Equality Act 2010
• Reform UK’s proposal to introduce a “Workplace Fairness Act” to replace the Equality Act
• Sir Keir Starmer appointing the first female cabinet Sscretary and head of the civil service
• Why misogyny in British politics remains a serious issue for women in public life
• Major Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) reforms expected next week — and why parents are worried the changes could make a broken system worse.

Responding to comments made by Harriet Harman, a Reform UK spokesperson said the party does not need “a pink bus” to attract women and defended its record on female representation. Reform UK also stated it remains committed to workplace protections against discrimination while criticising the Equality Act and what it describes as “DEI culture”.

This half-term special is packed with political analysis, listener questions, and sharp debate on the biggest UK political stories of the week.

Got a question for the Burner Phone?
📱 WhatsApp: 07934 200 444
📧 Email: electoraldysfunction@sky.uk

Subscribe for weekly UK politics, analysis, and behind-the-scenes insight from Harriet Harman, Ruth Davidson and Beth Rigby.

#PrinceAndrew #AndrewMountbattenWindsor #UKPolitics #ReformUK #KeirStarmer #EqualityAct #SEND #PoliticalPodcast #ElectoralDysfunction

episodes.title: Keir Starmer under fire over ‘paedo apologist’ claim
episodes.description:
Is Downing Street running a “boys’ club”? And how did two senior Labour figures with links to convicted paedophiles pass vetting? 

Keir Starmer has made it through the week, but the paedophile vetting scandal surrounding Peter Mandelson and Matthew Doyle is intensifying, raising serious questions about judgement, standards and culture at the heart of government. 

In this episode of Electoral Dysfunction, Beth Rigby, Ruth Davidson and Harriet Harman talk about: 

The “boys’ club” allegations inside Downing Street 

Whether women are being pushed onto a political “glass cliff” 

The fallout from the Peter Mandelson scandal 

Fresh scrutiny over Matthew Doyle’s peerage and vetting failures 

What “structural misogyny” in government actually means 

Harriet Harman’s proposal for a new First Secretary of State to drive culture change 

We also reveal what really happened behind the scenes in the dramatic weekend that led to Morgan McSweeney’s resignation and whether the Prime Minister is politically safe or simply buying time. 

This episode dives into UK politics, Labour Party leadership, Downing Street culture, vetting failures and women in power. 

A source close to the prime minister rejected suggestions of a "boys' club" in Downing Street, saying there were a number of "highly qualified and capable women that work in Number 10" including cabinet ministers and special advisers "across the whole government who are often forgotten in all of this". 

Follow us wherever you get your podcasts.

episodes.title: Have the Epstein files just brought down the UK government?
episodes.description:
Could this be the scandal that ends Keir Starmer’s career? 
 
The Prime Minister is under fire in one of the biggest political scandals of the century after appointing Peter Mandelson, despite his links to Jeffrey Epstein.  
 
Former Labour Deputy Leader Harriet Harman argues it could bring down the Prime Minister, questioning whether Starmer can survive the fallout or if it’s already too late to reset his leadership.  
 
She says Starmer’s response this week made him look “gullible and naive”.  
  
Beth Rigby, Ruth Davidson and Harriet Harman discuss: 
  
• Why the Mandelson appointment has caused such outrage 
• Whether Keir Starmer can recover politically 
• How power, loyalty and silence operate inside the political and media establishment 
• The network Mandelson built, and why it still matters today 
  
They also examine what this scandal says about modern British politics and accountability at the very top. 
  
Peter Mandelson denies any wrongdoing and has apologised to the victims of Jeffrey Epstein. 
  
Follow us wherever you get your podcasts.
